Name: RTX 4090
Performance: Absolute top-tier for 4K and beyond. Unmatched 3D design, rendering, and AI performance; ideal for professionals needing extreme compute power.

Name: RTX 4060
Performance: RTX 4060 – Great for 1080p gaming, decent 1440p. Entry-level productivity; limited VRAM and memory bandwidth can bottleneck heavier tasks.

Name: RTX 3090
Performance: Excellent 4K and VR gaming. Outstanding for 3D rendering, editing, and AI workloads thanks to 24 GB VRAM and strong CUDA performance.

Name: RTX 2080
Performance: Very capable 1440p/entry 4K gaming. Strong productivity performance for its generation with ray tracing and CUDA support.

Name: GTX 1660
Performance: Good 1080p gaming. Basic productivity support; lacks tensor/RT cores and NVENC advancements for serious workloads.

Name: GTX 1080
Performance: Still solid for 1080p/1440p gaming. OK for older rendering pipelines but lacks ray tracing, tensor cores, and modern acceleration.

Name: GTX 1060
Performance: Casual 1080p gaming. Light productivity use only; outdated for modern 3D workflows.

Name: GTX 970
Performance: Outdated; playable 900p/1080p in older titles. Poor productivity performance by today’s standards.

Name: RADEON RX 6400
Performance: Very entry-level 1080p gaming. Poor for 3D/design work; limited hardware acceleration and memory bandwidth.

Name: RADEON RX 6500 XT
Performance: Playable 1080p with compromises. Weak productivity; missing hardware encoders and only PCIe x4 support hurts.

Name: RADEON RX 6700 XT
Performance: Very good 1440p gaming. Strong in productivity where GPU OpenCL/Vulkan are used, but weaker in CUDA-dominant apps.

Name: RADEON RX 6800
Performance: Excellent 1440p and strong 4K gaming. Very competent for rendering, though not ideal for CUDA-based pipelines.
